Hi,

> >Can you not just make sure you include tests on plain-white and plain-black
> >images in every generation?
>
> >They presumably require outputs of +1 and -1 respectively?
>
>No.  The inputs are scaled to represent the relative brightness of the input
>pixels, not their actual brightness.
>   Thus, the networ will see a
>particular shape the same if it is nearly black as it will if it is gray, or
>if it is nearly white, or if it has high contrast or low contrast.

While this does not mean that the average value of any input image will be 
exactly zero, it must bias it towards zero.  Hence your result of the 
networks just evolving to return zero.

If you still want to evolve an averaging network then maybe you need to 
supply non-normalised data.  Otherwise, especially in the case where you 
are doing (1,1) - (9,9) then zero will always be a good guess.  I know 
averaging is only a step on the way to enlargement and you may be dropping 
that step, but if you were pursuing averaging then this might be a good idea.

To put this in a different context, you already use rotated, mirrored and 
inverted versions of each image.  Inversion changes the individual 
brighnesses but does not move the average any further from zero.  Maybe 
transformation of the images average brightness is another feature which 
you would want the networks behaviour to be invariant under...

Further to my previous post, however, the multiplexing part of the network 
must involve at least 100 neurones, maybe evolving that should be your 
first step?  OTOH, is multiplexing actually required as part of the 
problem, or did you just introduce it as part of your experimental 
setup.  Did those other papers you mentioned use coordinate inputs?  If 
not, then I'd strongly recommend some discussion of whether the experiment 
can be rephrased to avoid evolving this complex sub-network, such as fixing 
an "eye" size and scanning the eye over the whole image...

         Ian Badcoe
